text: [Music]
hello this is chef john from food wishes
comm with spanish mustard beef that's
kind of a lame name but i know what else
to call it it's a spanish influence
mustard marinade for a piece of beef to
grill so what I have here is some Dijon
mustard some smoked paprika one of my
favorite ingredients Spanish or
otherwise some Spanish sherry vinegar
which has a very nice
subtly sweet mellow flavor one of my
favorite all-purpose vinegars and some
very light olive oil or a giant pinch of
salt I'm going to whisk that up together
looks like a salad dressing doesn't it
higher acidity than a salad dressing but
the fat melting from the meat is going
to mix with that it's going to be
amazing by the way feel free to throw in
3 or 4 cloves of crushed garlic that
would be nice in this I left it out
wasn't in a garlicky mood all right now
this is going to work for any kind of
thin sliced meat this is sold as carne
asada in San Francisco it's just some
thinly sliced out of its flap meat or or
round or something anyway you can use
skirt steak you could use flank steak
you could use any thin sliced beef for
this alright once it's all coated I'm
going to let this marinate at room
temperature for 30 minutes or in the
refrigerator for an hour but you don't
want to go longer than that because this
is a high acid marinade and it will
actually start to cook the meat and
affect the texture alright and the rest
is easy a very very hot charcoal fire
and i grill these for about two minutes
per side I wanted to just barely cook
through and what I'm calling that
Spanish mustard it's really going to
keep things moist and tender and
delicious just don't go too far on the
cooking and don't go too far under you
like your meat rare fantastic cook this
at least medium-rare to medium you'll
get a better bite it's it's a little
chewy if it's rare okay
so I grilled up my pieces of beef man
that smelled good and by the way at this
point I was like why didn't you put
garlic in it you big dummy that would
have been good what are you going to do
learn from my mistakes and of course I'm
sure you never get tired of me telling
you let your meat rest 5 or 10 minutes
before you try eating it slice that
thinly against the grain so take 2 or 3
pieces
back them up slice it with a sharp knife
look at that beautiful and after you
slice it like that you may want to
sprinkle a nice pinch of kosher salt
over there you taste it though super
simple recipe for grilled beef I call it
Spanish mustard because it's got you
know a couple Spanish ingredients and I
couldn't think of another name and I
serve it simply put it on tortilla
little hot sauce cilantro man is that
good pictured here is my wife Michelle's
version she upgraded to select avocado
also very delicious by the way I don't
even have to tell you this would be good
on other stuff pork chicken fish I don't
know or you could try it let me know how
it is that fish anyway go to the site
all the ingredients are there and as
always enjoy
